content: The "Comprehensive Learning Assessment for Students and Schools (CLASS) Act" may be cited as the short title. Amendments are made regarding adequate yearly progress and assessments. Amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, including changes to continuous growth models, averaging procedures, and adequate yearly progress by group and subject. The "Comprehensive Learning Assessment for Students and Schools (CLASS) Act" is the short title for these amendments. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 focus on performance criteria for specific student groups in the same academic subject. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 require multiple measures of student academic achievement, including specific performance criteria for particular student groups in the same academic subject. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 now include a requirement for various measures of academic achievement, such as State report card indicators, performance index scores, student drop-out rates, and individual student achievement gains over time, broken down by student groups. Additionally, cut scores in the Act now consider the continuum of achievement by children. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 now includes measures of academic achievement like State report card indicators, performance index scores, student drop-out rates, and individual student achievement gains over time. Cut scores now consider the continuum of achievement by children within different levels. Amendments also remove the first score requirement for students retaking assessments. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to limit transfer options and supplemental services to students from failing groups. This includes using student results from subsequent administrations of assessments and specifying students who fail to make adequate yearly progress. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to restrict transfer options and supplemental services for students in failing groups, based on assessment results and inadequate yearly progress. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include assessing students with disabilities based on challenging academic content and achievement standards. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include assessing students with disabilities below grade level using state assessments. Students with limited English proficiency may have their progress measured differently under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, students with limited English proficiency will have their progress measured differently. This includes excluding students who have resided in the United States for less than 3 years to avoid measurement distortion. Additionally, there will be separate starting points for each group of students described in the act. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 specifies different measurement criteria for students with limited English proficiency, excluding those who have been in the US for less than 3 years to prevent distortion. The amendment allows states to set a higher minimum number of students with disabilities for reliable data compared to other student groups.
